history.content:
This is a really hard question to answer, mainly because there's a reason we don't have compulsory courses here at Berkeley: people forge their own paths, based on their interests and what they do outside of class, so it's hard to come up with a must-take list.

The only class I would say any CS/EE major should take (unless there's a really good reason not to) is CS 170, simply because it's not just an algorithms class, but an introduction to CS-style thinking about problems and proofs, which will help you no matter where you go in the CS/EE world.

Given the AI/ML hype, taking 189 is also a really good idea, just to get a sense of whether you like it or not; that being said, 189  does require significant mathematical maturity (and thus may not be the class for everyone), but if you can take it you definitely should at some point.

As for a specific number of upper-divs, it really depends on the person; some people I know will take upwards of 15 UDs by the time they graduate, others only 4/5 - I'd say take the first 5 you really really want to take, and then figure out what you want to take next.

----

I linked to a (nonstatistical) survey in @1093

----

Sahai has some thoughts at @4949

Hello everyone,

So, for a long time I've been wondering how many upper div courses I should take (Am a sophomore EECS major) in the department. Well, I know most of your answers are going to be something like, "take what interests you", but I think we can all agree that there are few select courses that every sensible CS/ EE student should take. For example, last I checked, the EECS department says that a student can graduate having taken only 4 upper-div EECS courses. Isn't this misleading in that the student might end up to be inadequately prepared? 

Also, does it matter which upper-divs I choose to take? I mean, there are so many upper-divs to choose from that it is almost impossible to tailor courses according to one's needs. Can someone share thoughts on classes they think every CS/EE major should have under their belt? (For both EE, and CS classes; separately depending on whether you're on the EE or CS side of the spectrum)
history.subject: SENSIBLE NUMBER OF CS/EE UPPER-DIVS TO TAKE
